history.content:
Mostly, in effect,  prerequisites are indeed sort of a strong recommendation with the proviso that faculty are able to enforce them by asking that students who don't meet them be kicked out of the class before the end of the third week of class.  

That seldom happens but it is possible and is completely at the discretion of the instructor.

This might sound like a stupid question, and something most people (including myself) probably just don't ever think about, because obviously a prerequisite course is just a course you have to take before you can take the next one.
But what does this actually mean? After taking a brief look at most of the discussions on prereqs on here, it doesn't seem clear to me, as it seems that anyone can somehow enroll in any course currently (as the new system cannot check for prerequisites).

Will a human actually check every single person's records to make sure they've taken the prerequisites listed for the course in question, or as of now do they just mean "if you haven't taken this prereq, there is a high chance you will fail or struggle in this class"?

I began wondering this because I'm currently enrolled in Physics 7B in the fall, but I haven't taken math 53 in Berkeley (but I just took the equivalent this summer at a community college). 53 is listed as a prereq for 7B, but I don't think the transferred course will show up on my records until a good while after the beginning of the semester. However, it seems unlikely that I would actually be removed from the class due to this; so are prerequisites just a sort of strong recommendation?
history.subject: What Do Course Prerequisites Actually Mean?
